raw_text:
Wales win in Rome
 
 Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory in Rome.
 
 Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams gave the visitors a 19-5 half-time advantage. Luciano Orquera did reply with one for Italy but second-half efforts from Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams and Robert Sidoli sealed victory. Fly-half Stephen Jones added four conversions as Wales maintained their superb start to this year's tournament. Starting full of confidence after their victory over England, the visitors scored the opening try after just four minutes. Diminutive wing Shane Williams fielded a kick ahead and danced past the onrushing Andrea Masi and Aaron Persico into the Italian half. His pass to Tom Shanklin appeared forward but when the centre was held up short, the ball was switched left and Michael Owen's long cut-out pass gave the lurking Thomas an easy run-in.
 
 Stephen Jones, who retained the kicking duties despite Gavin Henson's heroics against England, slotted an excellent conversion from wide out. Wales twice threatened further scores but failed to find the crucial pass, and Italy hit back out of the blue in the 11th minute.
 
 Henson, sporting gold boots rather than the silver variety that did for England, beat two players with ease out on the left touchline. But his attempted chip ahead was charged down by Orquera, who snaffled the loose ball and hared away from halfway to score in the right corner. With the Welsh line-out stuttering and Italy twice turning the visitors' scrum, the home side's forward power brought them back into it. But a clever high kick from Henson almost brought a try for Hal Luscombe when Roland de Marigny and Ludovico Nitoglia made a hash of claiming it as the ball bounced into touch.
 
 Wales regained control with a second try in the 21st minute, Henson lobbing up a high kick to the left corner where Shanklin jumped higher than Nitoglia to dot down his 15th Test try. Jones was unable to convert and De Marigny then hit the upright with a penalty attempt for Italy. Henson was also narrowly short with a long-range effort at goal, but Wales ended the half with a vital third score to give themselves some breathing space.
 
 Henson sent Luscombe streaking away and when he off-loaded to Martyn Williams, the flanker showed his nous to ground the ball against the padding of the post, Jones adding the conversion. Italy, who lost flanker Mauro Bergamasco with a head knock before half-time, built up a head of steam on the resumption. De Marigny landed a penalty to make it 19-8 and a Nitoglia break through the middle threatened a try only for the move to break down with a knock-on. But Wales put the outcome beyond doubt with two superb tries in four minutes before the hour. Their fourth after 53 minutes was sparked by another mazy run from Shane Williams, who beat several players with ease, and finished with a powerful angled run from lock Cockbain. Before Italy could recover from that blow, a strong surge from Gareth Thomas and great off-loads from Martyn Williams and replacement Kevin Morgan saw Shane Williams scamper over.
 
 With Jones converting both for a 33-8 lead, Wales had the luxury of sending on five more replacements for the final quarter. The icing on the cake came with a sixth try after more superb support work, Shane Williams and Ceri Sweeney combining to send Sidoli over in the left corner. The only downside for Wales was a hamstring injury suffered by Luscombe. But after back-to-back wins at the start of the tournament for the first time in 11 years, they will travel to Paris in a fortnight looking like genuine contenders.
 
 R de Marigny; Mirco Bergamasco, W Pozzebon, A Masi, L Nitoglia; L Orquera, A Troncon; A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni, S Dellape, M Bortolami (capt), A Persico, Mauro Bergamasco, S Parisse.
 
 G Intoppa, S Perugini, CA del Fava, D dal Maso, P Griffen, M Barbini, KP Robertson.
 
 G Thomas (capt); H Luscombe, T Shanklin, G Henson, S Williams; S Jones, D Peel; G Jenkins, M Davies, A Jones; B Cockbain, R Sidoli; J Thomas, M Williams, M Owen.
 
 R McBryde, J Yapp, I Gough, R Sowden-Taylor, G Cooper, C Sweeney, K Morgan.
 
 Andrew Cole (Australia).
llama3.2:1b:
Wales secured a six-try victory in Rome with a 33-8 win over Italy. 

The match began with Wales' try scored by Shane Williams after just four minutes, thanks to an early pass from Diminish wing Shane Williams. Wales struggled to maintain their lead but scored twice more before halftime. In the second half, they added two more tries. The first was scored in the 48th minute when Gareth Thomas ran into space and beat several players to score, while the second was scored six minutes later by Shane Williams after another mazy run.
llama3.2:3b: Wales won their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a 6-try victory in Rome. The visitors scored three tries before halftime and maintained their lead through two more tries in the second half, sealed by Robert Sidoli's try. Stephen Jones added four conversions, securing Wales' superb start to the tournament.
gemma2:2b: Wales won their first away game in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a 6-try victory in Rome.  The Welsh side scored tries by Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams before Luciano Orquera replied for Italy, but Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams, and Robert Sidoli sealed a comfortable win. Stephen Jones converted all the tries. Italy fought back through a penalty from Andrea De Marigny but Wales controlled the game with strong running and accurate passing.  After two more tries, Sidoli scored the sixth and final try for Wales before the end of the game.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a 6-0 half-time advantage over Italy. The visitors' six tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams secured this victory. Wales extended their start to the tournament with two more tries in the second half. The full-backs Shane Williams and Robert Sidoli added conversions. Wales won their first away match in a RBS Six Nations appearance since 2017.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Wales beat Italy 33-19 in a Six Nations match, securing their first away win in four years. Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams scored tries, with Wales maintaining an excellent start to the tournament.
qwen2.5:3b: Wales secured their first away win in the Six Nations for nearly four years with a comprehensive 33-8 victory over Italy in Rome. The match saw Wales score six tries, including those from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, Martyn Williams, Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams, and Robert Sidoli. Stephen Jones contributed five conversions. Wales maintained their strong start to the tournament and will head to Paris for their next match. Italy were without key players such as Mauro Bergamasco who suffered a head injury early in the game.
opencoder:1.5b:
Wales win in Rome

Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams gave the visitors a 19-5 half-time advantage. Luciano Orquera replied with one for Italy but second-half efforts from Brent Cockbain, Shane Williams and Robert Sidoli sealed victory.

Stephanie Jones added four conversions as Wales maintained their superb start to this year's tournament. The opening try after just four minutes was scored by the visitors in the right corner.

Hal Luscombe lobbed up a high kick to the left corner where Shanklin jumped higher than Nitoglia to dot down his 15th Test try.

Wales regained control with a second try in the 21st minute, Henson lobbed up a long-range effort at goal. Italy hit back out of the blue in the 11th minute.

Gareth Thomas and great off-loads from Martyn Williams and replacement Kevin Morgan saw Shane Williams scamper over after a tricky run from Luscombe.

Before Italy could recover from the blow, a strong surge from Gareth Thomas to the left corner blocked the ball against the padding of the post. The outcome was sparked by another mazy run from Shane Williams that led to Ceri Sweeney combining to send Sidoli over in the left corner.

Luscombe streaked away and when he off-loaded to Martyn Williams, the flanker showed his nous to ground the ball against the goal post. Italy built up a head of steam on the resumption, causing a try only for the move to break down with a knock-on.

Wales put the outcome beyond doubt with two superb tries in four minutes before the hour. Their fourth after 53 minutes was sparked by another mazy run from Shane Williams that led to Ceri Sweeney combining to send Sidoli over in the left corner. The only downside for Wales was a hamstring injury suffered by Luscombe.

After back-to-back wins at the start of the tournament for the first time in 11 years, they will travel to Paris in a fortnight looking like genuine contenders. R de Marigny; Mirco Bergamasco, W Pozzebon, A Masi, L Nitoglia; L Orquera, A Troncon; A Lo Cicero, F Ongaro, M Castrogiovanni, S Dellape, M Bortolami (capt), A Persico, Mauro Bergamasco, S Parisse.

G Intoppa, S Perugini, CA del Fava, D dal Maso, P Griffen, M Barbini, KP Robertson.

G Thomas (capt); H Luscombe, T Shanklin, G Henson, S Williams; S Jones, D Peel; G Jenkins, M Davies, A Jones; B Cockbain, R Sidoli; J Thomas, M Williams, M Owen.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text. The following is a possible summary:

Wales won their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory in Rome. Tries from Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin and Martyn Williams gave Wales a 19-5 half-time advantage. Fly-half Stephen Jones added four conversions as Wales secured their first away win of the year. Starting full of confidence after their victory over England, Wales scored the opening try after just four minutes. Diminutive wing Stephen Jones fielded a kick ahead and danced past the onrushing Andrea Masi and Aaron Persico into the Italian half. His pass to Tom Shanklin made it difficult for Italy to recover from that blow, but they were able to hold onto their possession and start building towards a try. Henson's attempted chip ahead was charged down by Orquera, who snaffled the loose ball and hared away from halfway. With the Welsh line-out stalling, Wales regained control of the game with a second try in the 21st minute. Luscombe broke through to goal for the third try, but Italy's defense held them back until the end of the match. Wales finished their first away win with a 33-8 lead and six tries to go before the half-time break.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so the user has given me a text about Wales winning the Six Nations against Italy in Rome and wants a summary. The output needs to be plain text with only the summary, no explanations or formatting. Let's see what they provided.

First, I need to read through the entire text carefully to understand the key points. It starts by mentioning Wales securing their first away win in four years, which is a big deal because it's nearly four years since that happened. Then it talks about how Wales got a six-try victory in Rome against Italy. The tries were scored by Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams, giving the visitors an 19-5 lead after half-time.

Next, Italy replied with one try, and they responded with two more tries towards the end. It mentions how Wales didn't find the crucial pass twice and how the line-out caused a crucial conversion by Jones to give them a lead. Also, Henson, who was on fire against England, had an attempt that went wide but Orquera scored in the right corner.

Then there's some details about the kick from Henson going into the box and another tackle by Henson almost scoring a try for Luscombe. It also mentions how Wales regained control with two more tries in four minutes, showing their line-out power.

Throughout this, it lists all the players involved and then ends with a note on the lineup for the next match against Paris. Finally, it gives some details about the kickers. 

Now, I need to make sure that when I summarize, I include all these key points without adding anything extra. The summary should be concise, including the main result, the reasons for the win, the teams' strategies, and any notable players or highlights.

I also notice that the user provided some additional lists of players, but since they're not part of the summary (as it's just a sentence), I can skip mentioning them. 

I'll start by stating that Wales secured their first away win in four years against Italy in Rome. Then mention the six-try victory to give an 19-5 lead. Highlight the fact that Wales had a solid lineup from England and maintained their strong start. Note that Henson's performance was key, especially his try that Orquera scored in the right corner. Also, mention that the line-out caused Jones to convert, giving Wales a critical advantage. 

I should include how Wales regrouped with two more tries in four minutes and how they built momentum after losing some early attempts. Mention Henson's attempt going wide but being caught out by Orquera for the goal. Include that the visitors were down 8-19 after half-time, which was a strong lead to keep.

Also, touch on Wales' line-out power to get two more tries in the final quarter and how they put their minds at rest with Jones converting both for a 33-8 advantage. Emphasize that despite losing to England, Wales showed resilience and leadership.

In conclusion, I need to state that Wales has shown genuine contenders for the tournament and look forward to their next match against Paris in two weeks.
</think>

Wales secured their first away win in four years with a six-try victory in Rome against Italy. Wales achieved an 19-5 lead at half-time after Jonathan Thomas, Tom Shanklin, and Martyn Williams' tries, setting the stage for their strong start to the tournament. Italy responded with one try but failed to find the crucial pass twice, losing track of possession twice and falling behind 8-19. Henson's attempt went wide but Orquera scored in the right corner, giving Wales a critical advantage with Jones converting both tries for a 33-8 advantage. Wales regrouped with two more tries in the final quarter, showcasing their line-out power to maintain momentum. Despite losing early attempts, Wales kept their minds at rest with Jones converting both again, leading them to win 45-29. Wales' line-out gave them another chance to score twice before the hour and showed resilience after a strong performance against England.
tinyllama:1.1b: Wales secured their first away win in the 2018 Six Nations Championship with a comprehensive victory over Italy, winning by 33 points to 8. The match was characterized by Wales' impressive backline support work and scoring by multiple tries to a rampaging Italian team. Wales started strong with several tries in the first half while Italy struggled to score, resulting in a 19-5 halftime lead for Wales. Despite having a hamstring injury suffered by one of their star players, Wales sent on five more replacement players for the final quarter and managed to secure a convincing victory.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Wales secured their first away win in the RBS Six Nations for nearly four years with a six-try victory against Italy. The team played superbly under the watchful eye of coach Steve Jones, and it was clear that they were relishing the opportunity to gain momentum on the road. With key players like Henson, Luscombe, and Nitoglia on the field, Wales proved to be an attacking force in both the first half and second half, putting up a 19-5 lead at the break.

The Italians tried their best to mount a comeback but they were unable to turn back the tide as Wales secured victory with a combination of powerful running, clever passing, and well-timed kicks. With the win under their belt, Wales will now look forward to facing France in Paris next weekend. The team's performance against Italy was nothing short of spectacular, and they are expected to make a strong impression on the tournament so far ahead.
